caption: Table 1: Single-scene video generation performances on VBench. For each video, 128 frames are synthesized for evaluation.
description: This table presents a quantitative comparison of different methods for generating single-scene videos using the VBench benchmark.  For each video generation method, it shows performance scores across several metrics: Subject Consistency (how well the main subject is maintained throughout the video), Background Consistency (how consistent the background is), Motion Smoothness (how smooth the motion is), Temporal Consistency (how consistent the video is over time), and Aesthetic Quality (overall visual quality).  Each method was evaluated by generating a video of 128 frames for each prompt.

content:
Approach                Subject        Consistency ↑↑\uparrow↑                Background        Consistency ↑↑\uparrow↑                Motion        Smoothness ↑↑\uparrow↑                Temporal        Flickering ↑↑\uparrow↑                Aesthetic        Quality ↑↑\uparrow↑
       FIFO-Diffusion (Kim et al. 2024)        93.96        96.17        96.36        93.59        60.12
       FreeNoise (Qiu et al. 2024)        95.07        96.52        96.57        95.06        61.26
       Ouroboros-Diffusion        95.73        96.82        97.77        95.82        61.17
caption: Table 2: Multi-scene video generation performances on VBench. For each video, 256 frames are synthesized for evaluation.
description: This table presents quantitative results of multi-scene video generation experiments using the VBench benchmark.  The experiments compared the performance of Ouroboros-Diffusion against three other state-of-the-art methods: FIFO-Diffusion, FreeNoise, and StreamingT2V.  For each method, 256 frames were generated for each video prompt, and the table displays the resulting scores across five key metrics: Subject Consistency, Background Consistency, Motion Smoothness, Temporal Flickering, and Aesthetic Quality. Higher scores indicate better performance on each metric.

content:

caption: Table 3: Performance contribution of each component (i.e., Coherent Tail Latent Sampling, SACFA and Self-Recurrent Guidance) in Ouroboros-Diffusion on single-scene video generation. For each video, 128 frames are synthesized for evaluation.
description: This table presents an ablation study evaluating the individual and combined contributions of three key components of the Ouroboros-Diffusion model to single-scene video generation. The components are: Coherent Tail Latent Sampling, Subject-Aware Cross-Frame Attention (SACFA), and Self-Recurrent Guidance.  The table shows how each component affects the performance metrics of Subject Consistency, Background Consistency, Motion Smoothness, Temporal Flickering, and Aesthetic Quality.  Each video in this experiment consisted of 128 frames.

content:
Model Motion Smoothness ↑bold-↑\bm{\uparrow}bold_↑ Temporal Flickering ↑bold-↑\bm{\uparrow}bold_↑
Gaussian Noise 95.88 93.38
Head Frame 97.51 95.87
Second-to-Last Frame (Ours) 97.73 96.12
caption: Table 4: Evaluation on the coherent tail latent sampling.
description: This table presents an ablation study on the coherent tail latent sampling method used in Ouroboros-Diffusion. It compares the performance of using Gaussian noise, the head frame, and the second-to-last frame (the proposed method) for generating the tail latent in the denoising process. The metrics used for comparison are Motion Smoothness and Temporal Flickering, evaluated on single-scene video generation.

content:
Model Subject Consistency ↑bold-↑\bm{\uparrow}bold_↑ Motion Smoothness ↑bold-↑\bm{\uparrow}bold_↑
w/o Guidance 94.04 95.88
Guidance with λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ=1 95.87 97.71
Guidance with λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ=0 96.00 97.71
Moving-Average (Ours) 96.06 97.73
caption: Table 5: Evaluation on the self-recurrent guidance.
description: This table presents the ablation study results on the self-recurrent guidance component of the Ouroboros-Diffusion model. It compares the model's performance in terms of Motion Smoothness and Temporal Flickering under different guidance strategies. The strategies include using no guidance, guidance using only the head frame, guidance using only the second-to-last frame (the proposed method), and guidance using a moving average of the frames.  The metrics show the effectiveness of using the second-to-last frame and moving average for better motion smoothness and temporal coherence.
